Problem:
Investigate a system characterized by the continuous-time Fourier transform (CTFT) of a signal \\(x(t)\\), denoted as \\(X(f)\\). Explore how the multiplication by a complex exponential \\(e^{2\\pi i f_0 t}\\) in the time domain, where \\(f_0\\) is a frequency offset, affects the transform.

By modifying the signal \\(x(t)\\) to \\(x(t)e^{2\\pi i f_0 t}\\) at t = 0 and then calculating the CTFT, will the spectrum \\(X(f)\\) simply shift by \\(f_0\\) in frequency without any additional changes?
Explanation: The multiplication by \\(e^{2\\pi i f_0 t}\\) in time domain corresponds to a frequency shift in the Fourier domain. This is a direct application of the modulation property of the Fourier transform, which states that multiplying a time-domain signal by a complex exponential results in a frequency shift of its spectrum by \\(f_0\\) without altering the shape or amplitude distribution of the spectrum.
